qas.question: The early courts' military conscription broke down around what year?
Warriors appointed to a province were called what?
Warriors appointed for specific tasks were called what?
Where did final authority over the military lie?
What was in the hands of the provincial aristocracy in he early courts?
What process allowed provincial aristocracy to take control slowly?
Who made up the imerial courts army?
What authority rested with the Japanese military class?

context: Under the early courts, when military conscription had been centrally controlled, <b4_0>military affairs<b4_0/> had been taken out of the hands of the provincial aristocracy. But as the system broke down after <a0_0>792<a0_0/>, local power holders again became the primary source of military strength. The re-establishment of an efficient military system was made gradually through <b5_0>a process of trial-and-error<b5_0/>. At that time the imperial court did not possess an army but rather relied on an organization of professional warriors composed mainly of <a1_0><b6_0>oryoshi<b6_0/><a1_0/>, which were appointed to an individual province and <a2_0>tsuibushi<a2_0/>, which were appointed over imperial circuits or for specific tasks. This gave rise to the Japanese military class. Nonetheless <b7_0>final authority<b7_0/> rested with the <a3_0>imperial court<a3_0/>.
